foundation.title: Foundation & Objectives
foundation.description: Capture the core intent so subsequent technical decisions stay anchored to outcomes.

questions.prompt: Provide the project codename or customer initiative name.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Opnix Refresh, Phoenix Revamp

questions.prompt: Select the project or product type that best describes this workstream.
questions.placeholder: Choose dominant delivery surface

questions.prompt: What problem does this initiative solve and for which users or customers?
questions.placeholder: Describe the primary user, their pain point, and the desired transformation.

questions.prompt: What measurable value or advantage should this solution deliver once successful?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Reduce onboarding time by 40%, increase retention, unlock a new market.

questions.prompt: How does this work align with current business strategy or OKRs?
questions.placeholder: Reference initiatives, KPIs, or mandates this project supports.

stakeholders.title: Stakeholders & Governance
stakeholders.description: Establish decision makers, communication cadence, and responsibility boundaries.

questions.prompt: Who is the executive sponsor and what decisions remain with them?
questions.placeholder: Name & role, plus escalation expectations.

questions.prompt: Who owns backlog prioritisation and scope trade-offs?
questions.placeholder: Name, role, availability, preferred contact channel.

questions.prompt: Who is accountable for technical direction and architecture sign-off?
questions.placeholder: Include backups for leave or timezone coverage.

questions.prompt: What is the agreed stakeholder communication cadence?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Weekly steering committee, daily stand-ups, async updates.

questions.prompt: List any areas requiring explicit RACI clarification (Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed).
questions.placeholder: Identify processes with unclear ownership so we can resolve them early.

outcomes.title: Success Criteria
outcomes.description: Define what success looks like both quantitatively and qualitatively.

questions.prompt: What primary success metrics must move and by how much?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Activation rate to 60%, NPS +10, MTTR < 30 minutes.

questions.prompt: What secondary metrics or guardrails must not regress?
questions.placeholder: Document supporting metrics (churn, latency, support volume, etc.).

questions.prompt: Describe qualitative indicators or anecdotes that would signal success or failure.
questions.placeholder: User feedback themes, stakeholder sentiment, demo reactions.

scope-boundaries.title: Scope: In & Out
scope-boundaries.description: Avoid scope creep by capturing explicit inclusions and exclusions.

questions.prompt: List the key capabilities or deliverables explicitly in scope.
questions.placeholder: Use bullet list for features, workflows, or technical outcomes.

questions.prompt: List the capabilities or areas explicitly out of scope for this iteration.
questions.placeholder: Note any tempting additions that must wait.

questions.prompt: Define "done" for this engagement (technical, product, and documentation completeness).
questions.placeholder: Include acceptance gates like demos, sign-offs, or compliance checks.

constraints.title: Constraints & Non-Negotiables
constraints.description: Capture immovable constraints so trade-offs are intentional.

questions.prompt: Document business or contractual constraints (launch dates, SLAs, regulatory deadlines).
questions.placeholder: List critical calendar commitments or contractual obligations.

questions.prompt: What technical standards or legacy requirements must we honour?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Must run on existing Kubernetes cluster, reuse auth provider, coding standards.

questions.prompt: Outline budgetary or tooling constraints that affect solution design.
questions.placeholder: Include licensing limits, cloud spend caps, approval processes.

architecture-baseline.title: Architecture Baseline
architecture-baseline.description: Understand the current and target architecture to plan increments safely.

questions.prompt: Summarise the current architecture or system topology we inherit.
questions.placeholder: Diagram references, key services, deployment model, observed pain points.

questions.prompt: Describe the target architecture vision or north-star state.
questions.placeholder: Note guiding principles, desired patterns, or technology shifts.

questions.prompt: List known technical debt hotspots that must be managed or paid down.
questions.placeholder: Include brittle modules, missing tests, scaling bottlenecks.

runtime-decisions.title: Runtime & Framework Decisions
runtime-decisions.description: Lock in primary languages, frameworks, and supporting libraries.

questions.prompt: Select the primary implementation language for this project.
questions.placeholder: Choose dominant language

questions.prompt: Preferred framework or stack for the UI/API layer?
questions.placeholder: Will update based on language

questions.prompt: List critical supporting libraries, design systems, or SDKs we must integrate.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Chakra UI, Tailwind, gRPC clients, analytics SDKs.

data-domain.title: Data & Domain
data-domain.description: Capture how data flows, its lifecycle, and governance expectations.

questions.prompt: Identify the core domain entities and relationships that matter most.
questions.placeholder: Use nouns that appear in user stories (e.g., Account, Workspace, Invoice).

questions.prompt: What upstream data sources or feeds do we consume?
questions.placeholder: Internal services, external vendors, manual imports, IoT devices.

questions.prompt: Describe expected data volume and velocity characteristics.
questions.placeholder: Peak throughput, batch windows, retention requirements.

questions.prompt: What data governance, lineage, or cataloguing practices must we follow?
questions.placeholder: Refer to privacy policies, GDPR, SOC2 controls, or data residency rules.

integrations.title: Integrations
integrations.description: Map inbound/outbound integrations to de-risk external dependencies early.

questions.prompt: Who consumes our outputs and through which interfaces?
questions.placeholder: Other internal teams, partners, public clients, reporting pipelines.

questions.prompt: Which external systems or APIs do we rely on?
questions.placeholder: List providers, auth mechanisms, rate limits, sandbox availability.

questions.prompt: Document critical integration failure modes and required fallbacks.
questions.placeholder: Timeout strategies, retries, circuit breakers, manual overrides.

security-compliance.title: Security & Compliance
security-compliance.description: Ensure the solution adheres to required security posture from day one.

questions.prompt: List mandatory compliance or certification requirements (e.g., SOC2, HIPAA).
questions.placeholder: Include evidence expectations, auditors, or control owners.

questions.prompt: How must users, services, and machines authenticate?
questions.placeholder: SSO providers, MFA, service accounts, token expiry policies.

questions.prompt: Describe the authorisation scheme (roles, ABAC, tenant isolation).
questions.placeholder: Role hierarchy, permission granularity, policy management tooling.

questions.prompt: What security monitoring, alerting, and response processes must we integrate?
questions.placeholder: SIEM integration, threat detection rules, incident response plans.

quality-strategy.title: Quality & Testing
quality-strategy.description: Define how we assure quality throughout delivery.

questions.prompt: Outline the testing pyramid (unit, integration, contract, e2e) and ownership.
questions.placeholder: Mention tools, coverage targets, and gating criteria.

questions.prompt: List required non-functional tests (performance, load, accessibility, chaos).
questions.placeholder: Include frequency and tooling expectations.

questions.prompt: What makes a feature story "ready" for implementation?
questions.placeholder: Acceptance tests, data requirements, UX assets, analytics tagging.

operations-reliability.title: Operations & Reliability
operations-reliability.description: Plan for live operations, SLOs, and incident readiness.

questions.prompt: What availability/SLO or error budget targets do we commit to?
questions.placeholder: e.g., 99.9% monthly uptime, <1% error rate.

questions.prompt: How should the system scale (horizontal, vertical, auto-scaling rules)?
questions.placeholder: Include expected peak events and traffic growth assumptions.

questions.prompt: Which logging, metrics, tracing, and alerting tools are mandated?
questions.placeholder: Grafana, Datadog, OpenTelemetry, PagerDuty runbooks, etc.

questions.prompt: Outline on-call rotations, escalation paths, and incident response expectations.
questions.placeholder: Include SLAs for P0/P1 incidents and communication templates.

deployment-release.title: Deployment & Release
deployment-release.description: Control how changes move from idea to production safely.

questions.prompt: List environments and promotion strategy (dev, staging, prod, canary).
questions.placeholder: Include data refresh rules, access controls, parity expectations.

questions.prompt: What is the expected release cadence and change management process?
questions.placeholder: Continuous deployment, scheduled releases, freeze periods.

questions.prompt: Describe rollback, feature flag, and kill-switch strategies.
questions.placeholder: Automated rollback, database migration strategy, toggle ownership.

ai-recovery.title: AI Remediation & Safeguards
ai-recovery.description: Ensure the system can recover from or prevent AI-induced regressions.

questions.prompt: Document known AI-assisted changes that introduced regressions or drift.
questions.placeholder: Reference incidents, dates, and affected components.

questions.prompt: What guardrails must be in place for future AI-assisted changes?
questions.placeholder: Review processes, mandatory tests, human-in-the-loop checkpoints.

questions.prompt: List critical scenarios that always require manual validation before release.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Payments, compliance workflows, data migrations.

documentation-enablement.title: Documentation & Enablement
documentation-enablement.description: Plan how knowledge will be captured and handed off.

questions.prompt: Who needs documentation (end users, support, engineers, auditors)?
questions.placeholder: List audiences and expected artefacts (runbooks, FAQs, onboarding guides).

questions.prompt: What training or enablement sessions are required?
questions.placeholder: Workshops, internal demos, office hours, certification requirements.

questions.prompt: Describe knowledge transfer expectations at engagement end.
questions.placeholder: Code walkthroughs, paired sessions, documentation reviews.

risks-assumptions.title: Risks, Assumptions & Open Questions
risks-assumptions.description: Make uncertainties explicit so action owners can be assigned.

questions.prompt: Enumerate the top risks that could derail scope, schedule, or quality.
questions.placeholder: Include probability, impact, and mitigation ideas.

questions.prompt: List critical assumptions that must be validated early.
questions.placeholder: Dependencies on other teams, vendor commitments, dataset availability.

questions.prompt: Capture unanswered questions that need follow-up interviews or research.
questions.placeholder: Assign owners and due dates when possible.

web-experience.title: Web Experience
web-experience.description: Design expectations specific to responsive web applications.

questions.prompt: Which design system, style guide, or component library must we follow?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Internal design system v3, Material UI, Tailwind tokens.

questions.prompt: List required responsive breakpoints and critical UX flows per device.
questions.placeholder: Mobile-first strategy, tablet optimisations, kiosk mode needs.

questions.prompt: Define performance budgets (TTI, CLS, LCP, bundle size) for web delivery.
questions.placeholder: Include measurement tooling (Lighthouse, WebPageTest).

accessibility-seo.title: Accessibility & Discoverability
accessibility-seo.description: Ensure web properties meet accessibility and SEO standards.

questions.prompt: Which accessibility standards and target level (e.g., WCAG AA) must we hit?
questions.placeholder: Document audit cadence, tooling, and assistive technology coverage.

questions.prompt: List SEO requirements (metadata, structured data, sitemap strategy).
questions.placeholder: Include content governance, internationalisation, canonical rules.

content-workflow.title: Content Workflow
content-workflow.description: Clarify how content is created, approved, and deployed.

questions.prompt: Where does content originate and who approves it?
questions.placeholder: CMS integration, editorial calendar, localization requirements.

api-contracts.title: API Contracts
api-contracts.description: Establish the API's external surface and governance expectations.

questions.prompt: Identify your API consumers and their critical use cases.
questions.placeholder: Internal services, partners, public developers.

questions.prompt: What versioning and deprecation policy must we follow?
questions.placeholder: Semantic versioning, sunset timelines, change notifications.

questions.prompt: Define latency, throughput, and availability expectations for the API.
questions.placeholder: p95 latency < 200ms, 99.9% uptime, regional failover.

api-observability.title: API Observability
api-observability.description: Ensure APIs are monitored and traceable end-to-end.

questions.prompt: What request/response logging or auditing is required?
questions.placeholder: PII scrubbing, correlation IDs, retention period.

questions.prompt: Define alert thresholds for error rates, saturation, or downstream failures.
questions.placeholder: Pager thresholds, dashboards, anomaly detection.

api-governance.title: API Governance
api-governance.description: Clarify standards for schema design, documentation, and SDKs.

questions.prompt: Which schema guidelines or linters must we adopt?
questions.placeholder: OpenAPI style guide, GraphQL naming conventions.

questions.prompt: Outline developer experience expectations (docs, SDKs, quickstarts).
questions.placeholder: Portal requirements, code samples, sandbox tokens.

mobile-delivery.title: Mobile Delivery
mobile-delivery.description: Plan for store releases and mobile-specific constraints.

questions.prompt: Which platforms are targeted (iOS, Android, others) and with what approach?
questions.placeholder: Native, cross-platform, shared code percentages.

questions.prompt: Document release, review, and compliance requirements for app stores.
questions.placeholder: Beta programs, TestFlight/Play Console workflows.

mobile-experience.title: Mobile Experience
mobile-experience.description: Capture expectations for mobile UX and offline behaviour.

questions.prompt: How should the app behave offline or with degraded connectivity?
questions.placeholder: Caching strategy, conflict resolution, sync windows.

questions.prompt: List native capabilities to integrate (push, camera, biometrics).
questions.placeholder: Specify permission handling, fallback experiences.

questions.prompt: What minimum OS versions and devices must we support?
questions.placeholder: Include sunset policy for older devices.

desktop-distribution.title: Desktop Distribution
desktop-distribution.description: Plan installers, auto-update, and signing requirements.

questions.prompt: How will the desktop app be distributed (app stores, direct download, enterprise)?
questions.placeholder: Include code signing, notarisation, MSI/PKG packaging requirements.

questions.prompt: Describe the update strategy and rollback mechanism for desktop clients.
questions.placeholder: Delta updates, silent installs, user prompts.

hardware-dependencies.title: Hardware & Peripheral Dependencies
hardware-dependencies.description: Capture hardware integrations or specialised device support.

questions.prompt: List required hardware integrations (scanners, printers, sensors) and drivers.
questions.placeholder: Include vendor contacts, certification needs.

questions.prompt: Document corporate IT policies affecting deployment (GPOs, VDI, proxies).
questions.placeholder: Mention packaging formats, security scans, whitelisting processes.

package-distribution.title: Package Distribution
package-distribution.description: Set expectations for how libraries are published and consumed.

questions.prompt: Which registries or artifact repositories host releases?
questions.placeholder: npm, PyPI, internal Artifactory, GitHub Packages.

questions.prompt: Are there restrictions on bundle size, transitive dependencies, or install scripts?
questions.placeholder: State policy for optional peer dependencies, native extensions.

versioning-governance.title: Versioning & Backward Compatibility
versioning-governance.description: Protect consumers with predictable versioning and changelog practices.

questions.prompt: Describe your semantic versioning or release policy.
questions.placeholder: How breaking changes are communicated, LTS branches, deprecation policy.

questions.prompt: What automated compatibility tests must run before release?
questions.placeholder: Consumer contract tests, fixture suites, sample apps.

adoption-readiness.title: Adoption & Support
adoption-readiness.description: Enable downstream teams to adopt the package confidently.

questions.prompt: Specify required documentation artefacts (reference, guides, examples).
questions.placeholder: API reference, cookbook, migration guides, changelog detail.

questions.prompt: Define support expectations (SLAs, channels, issue tracker triage).
questions.placeholder: Open-source vs internal support, response time commitments.

frontend-state-management.title: Frontend State & Composition
frontend-state-management.description: Clarify how UI state, routing, and component composition should be handled.

questions.prompt: What state management patterns or libraries must be used?
questions.placeholder: Redux Toolkit, Zustand, Vuex, context isolation rules.

questions.prompt: Detail routing, code splitting, and data fetching patterns for the UI.
questions.placeholder: SSR vs CSR, suspense boundaries, prefetching.

edge-rendering.title: Edge Rendering & Caching
edge-rendering.description: Capture policies for edge rendering platforms (e.g., Next.js, SvelteKit).

questions.prompt: Define caching, ISR/SSG, and revalidation strategies.
questions.placeholder: Cache lifetimes, surrogate keys, purge processes.

frontend-architecture.title: Angular Architecture Decisions
frontend-architecture.description: Set module structure, dependency injection, and tooling standards for Angular projects.

questions.prompt: Describe Angular module boundaries, lazy loading, and shared component strategy.
questions.placeholder: Feature modules, shell architecture, Nx workspace guidelines.
